thread.title: Democrats reject bill on CDOT spending transparency

title: Democrats reject bill on CDOT spending transparency
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Democrats reject bill on CDOT spending transparency Democrats on the Transportation Legislative Review Committee (TLRC) opposed a Republican effort Wednesday to draft a bill requiring CDOT to document why it chose to fund certain bridge projects through the "FASTER" program, which generates repair funds through increased car-registration fees. Post to Facebook Democrats reject bill on CDOT spending transparency Democrats on the Transportation Legislative Review Committee (TLRC) opposed a Republican effort Wednesday to draft a bill requiring CDOT to document why it chose to fund certain bridge projects through the "FASTER" program, which generates repair funds through increased car-registration fees. Check out this story on 9news.com: http://on9news.tv/1KPqThc Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Democrats reject bill on CDOT spending transparency Denver Business Journal, news source 12:26 p.m. MDT October 1, 2015 Five bridges on West Sixth Avenue near Interstate 25 are to be replaced. (Photo: CDOT) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
DENVER BUSINESS JOURNAL - An audit critical of the Colorado Department of Transportation for its lack of clear prioritizing for bridge funding was enough to draw rebukes from the Legislative Audit Committee last month — but apparently the audit was not scathing enough to move the legislative committee that oversees CDOT to demand more transparency from it. 
Democrats on the Transportation Legislative Review Committee (TLRC) — a combination of the state House and Senate transportation committees that meets even when the Legislature is out of session — opposed a Republican effort Wednesday to draft a bill requiring CDOT to document why it chose to fund certain bridge projects through the "FASTER" program, which generates repair funds through increased car-registration fees. 
Read more from the Denver Business Journal: http://bit.ly/1FL6qLe .
